questions.statement: Organisations are real, just like physical objects
Events in organisations are caused by deeper, underlying mechanisms
The social world we inhabit is a world of multiple meanings, interpretations and realities
‘Organisation’ is not a solid and static thing but a flux of collective processes and practices.
People believe to be true what they find useful.
Organisational research should provide scientific, objective, accurate and valid explanations of how the organizational world really works.
Theories and concepts never offer completely certain knowledge, but researchers can use rational thought to decide which theories and concepts are better than others
Concepts and theories are too simplistic to capture the full richness of the world.
What generally counts as ‘real’, ‘true’ and ‘valid’ is determined by dominant political ideologies.
The value of knowledge is that it enables things to be done successfully
Researcher values and beliefs must be excluded from the research process.
Researchers must try to be as objective and realistic as they can
Researchers’ values and beliefs are key to their interpretations of the social world.
Researchers should openly and critically discuss their own values and beliefs.
Research shapes and is shaped by what the researcher believes and doubts.
The purpose of research is to discover facts and regularities, and predict future events.
The purpose of organisational research is to offer an explanation of how and why organisations and societies are structured.
The purpose of research is to create new understandings that allow people to see the world in new ways.
The purpose of research is to examine and question the power relations that sustain conventional thinking and practices.
The purpose of research is to solve problems and inform future practice.
Things that cannot be measured have no meaning for the purposes of research.
Organisational theories and research findings should be evaluated in terms of their explanatory power of the causes of organisational behaviour.
To be meaningful, social research must include participants’ own interpretations of their experiences, as well as researchers’ interpretations.
Absences and silences in the world around us are at least as important as what is prominent and obvious.
Meaning emerges out of our practical, experimental and critical engagement with the world.
Human behaviour is determined by natural forces.
People’s choices and actions are always limited by the social norms, rules and traditions in which they are located.
Individuals’ meaning-making is always specific to their experiences, culture and history.
Structure, order and form are human constructions
People can use organisational routines and customs creatively to instigate innovation and change.
